concept.title: About Functions
concept.shortdesc: Explanation about functions in Excel and how to use them.

conbody.p: Excel has more than 300 built-in functions to perform a variety of operations. Features of the functions are divided into several categories:

A category can be useful when you are looking for a particular function. For example, if you are looking for a function to calculate the repayment of a loan, then this function can be found in the Financial category. Also, there are other categories: All, Most recently used and User defined.
With most of the features you need to specify what values or contents of cells the function should use in the calculation. These entries are called arguments.

All functions in Excel have the same construction (syntax):
They begin with the equal sign =.
Then the function's name.
Then round brackets (parentheses) enclosing the arguments. The arguments are separated by the so-called argument separator the comma (,). The argument separator used by Excel depends on a Windows setting. Default is the comma for English versions and a semicolon for the Dutch versions. You can change this through the control panel of Windows.
The arguments may include numbers, texts, operations, or also other functions.
conbody.note: The function's name and the separation of arguments depends on the used language version in Microsoft Office.
